titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Tuesday—

At the close of the Session of Congress, I find a number of unanswered Letters upon my files, and the files themselves in no small disorder— I received this morning a Letter from my Son Charles stating that Mr Phineas Foster had agreed to take up Midshipman Joseph H. Adams’s Bill for 100 dollars drawn in favour of John N. Todd, and I went to the U.S. Branch Bank—and paid and took it up with 1 dollar 75 cents for the protest— There are sundry other very minute matters which occupied my time, but with which I did nothing— I wrote three short Letters to Lieutt. T. B. Adams—to J. P. B. Storer, and tocompleted the diary minutes of the last three days, and arranged my Letters received in the last half year in three alphabetical files of two Months each— My practice of preserving all the Letters that I receive accumulates papers to such a degree that I often doubt whether it would not be a better role to preserve none— It would be certainly more convenient— It is difficult to discriminate between papers to be destroyed and papers to be retained— Nine tenths of the Letters that I have received in the course of my life are not worth preserving— Perhaps I might say the same of 49 in 50 or 99 in 100— The weather was oppressively warm, and in the evening at 8 O’Clock I went with my wife and Mary to an Oratorio at St. John’s Church— The music was chiefly from Handel—the performers few and indifferent— “Let the bright Seraphim” brought Ealing to my memory; and the Star of Bethlehem reminded me of the Worcester Cattle Show and evening concert at Worcester on the 11th. of October 1826, where I first heard it—how much have I needed the light of the Star since that day?— How much more am I to need it hereafter? But why art thou cast down? o my Soul, and why art thou disquieted within me?— Hope and still Hope.

On the last day of the Session—Mahlon Dickerson was nominated and appointed Secretary of the Navy, and William Wilkins Minister to Russia in his stead— Levi Woodbury had been previously transferred from the Navy to the Treasury Department, and John Forsyth appointed Secretary of State in the place of Louis M’Lane resigned.
2. V. Wednesday.

Wrote three short Letters; to Midshipman Joseph H. Adams in answer to one from him, written last February—to George Tucker, a Professor at the University of Virginia, and which leaves me to make enquiries at the Secretary’s Office in Boston—and one to Thomas Hobart of Hanson, with a copy of the Bill reported by the Committee of Roads and Canals, containing the provision for improvement of the Navigation of North River—Massachusetts— I received a Letter from Anthony Collamore at Pembroke, with enquiries to sustain a claim of widow Averick Thomas— I took the Letter to the Pension Office, where the discharge of Isaac Thomas a Revolutionary Soldier was found, and Mr Edwards the Commissioner of Pensions afterwards sent me a written answer to my enquiry— I called at the Navy Department where I saw the new Secretary Mahlon Dickerson— I left with him the Letter to Midshipman Joseph H. Adams, and spoke to him of the practice among the youngest Officers of the Navy of contracting debts beyond their ability to pay,—and of their being encouraged to this by the Pursers— I thought it required some new and severe regulation to restrain it— He concurred in this opinion and promised to issue such a regulation. At the War Department I spoke to Mr Cass of the appropriation for erecting a Monument over the remains of General Brown, which at my motion was placed under the direction of the Secretary of War. He said he would direct an Officer of the Engineers to prepare and shew me a design for the Monument and he requested me to write an Inscription for it which I promised to do— I spoke to him also of the appropriation of 100000 dollars for the fortifications of Georges Island in the Harbour of Boston, and asked him if the work would be commenced this year— He said it would if there should not be a deficiency of funds in the Treasury— I had a long conversation with him upon this, and upon the resistance to the appropriation for Surveys, and to the assaults upon the Military Academy at West-Point, all by the most devoted partisans of the President— He was not very explicit in his answers, and spoke of the expediency of reducing the number of the Cadets at West-Point to 200. But denied that the President had any hostile feeling to the Institution— Excessive heat— Fahrenheit 90.
3. V. Thursday

Mrs Adams spent the day at her brother’s— He has been extremely ill, but is believed to be now out of danger— I bathed this morning with my Son John in the Potowmack, and swam a few minutes— I still find the exercise delightful— I went to the General Post Office, but the Postmaster General Barry was not there I saw his Assistant Selah R. Hobbie, and left with him the Affidavits which I had received yesterday from F. A. Kingsbury; shewing that Mr Linnfield had been deceived in executing his contract for carrying the mail from Braintree to Randolph last February— The contract was changed without his being aware of it— I read Mr Kingsbury’s Letter to Mr Hobbie who took minutes of it and promised to send me a written answer upon the subject— I walked home with the Thermometer of Fahrenheit at 90— Lieutenant Bartlett called upon me by direction of the Secretary of War, with a design for the monument of General Brown; a fluted broken column, upon a cubic pedestal—and he said the Secretary had directed him to take such Inscription as I should write— I had some conversation with Lieutt. Bartlett on the mode of executing the monument, and it occurred to me that it would be well to write to General Brown’s brother concerning it— I wrote three Letters—one to Lieutt. Wilkes thanking him for his invitation to me to visit his observatory on Capitol Hill; which I have been obliged to postpone— One to Anthony Collamore at Pembroke, with answers to his enquiries in behalf of Widow Averick Thomas—and one to George Washington La Fayette, of condolence upon the decease of his father—and of Enquiries— This brought me to reflect upon the perilous and burdensome task I have undertaken to perform during the next Session of Congress, which weighs most oppressively upon me— About one O’Clock afternoon came up a very heavy thunder-gust which passed down, and crossed the river, and was succeeded by others all the afternoon and evening, with very moderate rain— I took up and partly read the work of Messrs de Beaumont and de Tocqueville, upon the Penitentiary System in the United States—
4. V. Friday.

Independence day— My Son John’s birthday— He is 31— Day of my father’s death— This threefold anniversary impresses me with an awful solemnity which I cannot waste in frivolous banqueting; and still less in mere political party carousals— I would rather devote it partly to humiliation and prayer, partly to useful occupation and the remainder to family social conviviality— I had invitations to whig celebrations at Philadelphia and at Boston, both of which I declined— My wife spent the whole day at her brothers; he is convalescent but yet very ill, and Mr Frye has also been suddenly seized, and is confined to his bed. I spent the day at home, and wrote Letters to the Revd. Jasper Adams, President of the College at Charleston South Carolina; to Thomas Hobart of Hanson Massachusetts with

I read over again Mr Jasper Adamss address which had struck me much when I received it, and upon which I had wanted time to reflect before I undertook to answer it— Indefatigable Industry is his great law of success in life, and there is perhaps no better Law that can be taught— But how much of success in life depends upon chance— How much upon temper?— How much upon address? How much upon intrigue? How much upon dishonesty—upon villainy? upon all the worst of human passions?— O how indispensable is another world to repair the injustice of this? And how little is the fruit of upright intentions and unremitting toil?— I dined with my children, and read de Beaumont, and de Tocqueville upon the Penitentiary Systems and the Quixotism of moral reformations— Commodore Morris and his Son, and Genl House were this day my only visitors— They had been at the President’s but his Porter informed them that he received only the Heads of Departments this day— The day was cloudy with one or two thunder-showers— There was a dinner attended by a small party of Jackson subalterns— And a few sky-rockets in the Evening— It was past nine when my wife came home from her brother’s—
5. V. Saturday— From Washington to Baltimore.

Mrs Adams had determined to proceed with the Carriage and horses to Baltimore this morning that I might overtake her at Night, in the Stage that left Washington at 2. P.M— But in consequence of her brother’s illness and that of Mr Frye, and of the excessive heat of the weather, she determined to remain a day or two longer, and rejoin me at Philadelphia, or follow me on to Quincy— I had hesitated whether I should not also postpone my departure, but she went early this morning to her brother’s and sent word that both he and Mr Frye were much better, so that I concluded to proceed, as I had promised Mr W B Reed to be in Philadelphia on Monday Morning— I wrote a Letter to Mr Samuel Brown, of Brownsville, New-York, in answer to one received some weeks since from him, and enclosing to him the design made by Lieutenant Bartlett, for the monument to General Jacob Brown. I settled and balanced my account at the U.S. Branch Bank, and called at the Department of State, where I found Mr John Forsyth installed as Secretary— I left with him my Letter to George W. La Fayette which he promised to forward with the earliest despatches to Mr Livingston— He said he had received this morning despatches from Mr Barton the Secretary of Legation at Paris giving an account of the funeral of Genl. La Fayette— No disorders had taken place, as had been much apprehended— At half past one O’Clock the Stage of Stockton and Stokes took me up, somewhat hurried, owing to a visit of an hour and a half from Coll. Thomas, who told me much gossiping news.— I left my Son John, his wife and two children with an indescribable pang—though with the hope to find them well here again in four months— I came as fast as the Stage would bring me with roads heavy from recent rains and a blazing Sun, Fahrenheit at 90. to Barnum’s Hotel at Baltimore, where I alighted at half past 8 in the Evening, obtained a Bed chamber, and soon after nine was in bed— I had five fellow-travellers in the Stage, and there were two outside passengers—no woman, and only two of the men decently well-bred— Among them was one dark mulatto— I had not I think ever before South of Mason and Dixon’s line seen a coloured man as an inside passenger— His dress was good, and his deportment not obtrusive— About 6 miles short of Baltimore the Jack of our Stage broke, and I was transferred to another of the line in which were more gentlemanly companions, and a woman and child—
6. IV.30. Sunday— From Baltimore to Philadelphia.

At precisely six this morning, I left the wharf at Baltimore, in the Steam-boat George Washington Captain Trippe, at a quarter past ten we landed at French town, and in fifty-five minutes crossed in the Rail-road Cars to New Castle— There took the Steamer Robert Morris and precisely at two landed at Chesnut Street wharf Philadelphia— I walked to United States Hotel Dorrances and took a Bed-chamber— Called upon Mr Webster who is in the same house. Steam-boat fellow-passengers whom I knew were Mr James Strong, heretofore a member of Congress from New-York— Mr Thomas Allen of St. Augustine Florida, a man much acquainted with me when I had offices to bestow, and to whom I gave one in Florida— Somewhat eccentric, but a well meaning and worthy man— MrBeaumont, a member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania, with his daughter and Miss Stevens a daughter of the Governor of Maryland— Mr Beaumont told me he had been much indisposed, since the close of the Session of Congress, and was yet quite unwell— Mrs Asbury Dickens with her very pretty daughter Julia and Mrswith her Son sometime a Cadet at West-Point, now an Officer of Engineers, and her daughter who told me she was at the School of the Visitation Nuns at Georgetown, when I crowned Miss Yturbide there in 1828. She said she had continued there five years afterwards— The Son has a furlough for a year, and they are to embark at New-York for Liverpool on the 15th.— It was one of the most intensely hot days of the Summer, and our only occupation was to keep as cool as possible— But 8 hours transmitted us from Baltimore to Philadelphia— After resting a few minutes I went out intending to go to the Unitarian Church, but I chanced to find only the tenth Presbyterian Church, where I heard a young man preach from Daniel 5.27. “Thou art weighed in the balance and found wanting”—which he told us would happen to us all, unless saved by faith in Christ—a gentleman accosted me after Church and told me Mrs Roberdeau was there— Mr W. B. Reed called upon me, and I promised to go with him, and give my deposition at 1/2 past ten to-morrow morning— In the Evening I went and passed an hour with Mr John Sergeant— Mr Southard and Mr Nicholas Biddle came in while I was there— Sergeant and Biddle accompanied me home to my lodgings
7. V. Monday.

Another intensely hot day— I wrote the Diary of the last two days and a Letter to my Son John— Called on Mr Webster, and met at his chamber Mr Mangum another member of the Committee of the Senate appointed to investigate the Bank, and to sit during the recess— Mr Webster read the draught of the Letter that he had prepared as Chairman of this Committee to the President of the U.S. Bank, announcing their appointment and the enquiries they proposed— Conversing with those Gentlemen I suggested to them some enquiries concerning what was understood by the Banks in their returns under the denomination of specie— They sometimes include under it, more than gold and Silver— Mr W T Smith at 1/2 past ten brought me a note from Mr W. B. Reed, and went with me in his stead to the Grand Jury room where Justice Milner took my deposition, respecting the disaster which happened on the railroad from Perth Amboy to Bordentown last November— There are three actions against the proprietors of the rail-way line of Stages for injury suffered by Mrs Bartlett, by her child, and by Miss Whitehorn her Sister—and for which my deposition is to be used— The Magistrate was three hours in taking my deposition, which I then subscribed, and he administered to me the Oath. Mr Joseph R Ingersoll, with Mr Smith for Mr Reed, attended on the part of Lieutt. Bartlett and the Plaintiffs and Mr Kittera, with two other young men on the part of the Defendants— They took no Testimony of what happened after the accident respecting the Coroner’s Inquest— After giving the deposition I went to the U.S. Bank—called over at the Hotel to enquire if my wife had arrived but she had not— I met there Mr Tyler U.S. Senator and a member of the investigating Committee just arrived in the Boat from Baltimore, he having boarded the Boat in the Chesapeake Bay, coming himself from point Comfort— I went from the Bank home with Mr Biddle and dined with him— He shewed me a late Edition of Giraldus Cambrensis upon Wales—in two Quarto volumes, edited by a Baronet named Hoare and published in 1806— The party were judge Baldwin, Mr W. Meredith—Mr J H Powell, Mr W. S. Coxe, Mr H King, Mr Harper, Mr Binney, Coll. Watmough, and Mr Harmar Denny; with Mr Biddle’s Son— Mr Binney accompanied me home to my lodgings— Mr John Connell had called upon me this morning—and invited me to dine with him to morrow.
8. IV:30. Tuesday.

Breakfasted with Mr Webster, and agreed to go with him to-morrow Morning for New-York; but I afterwards received a Letter from my Son John, written on Sunday, and mentioning the arrangements made by my wife, with a view to her arrival here, by the Boat from Newcastle to-morrow. I then determined to wait for her— Wrote a Letter to my Son Charles, informing him as far as I was able when he may expect us at Quincy— The excessive heat of the day, equal to any thing that I ever experienced disqualified me for all exertion, and almost for all exercise— I only visited Mr Binney whom I found at his Office, and who introduced his Son to me. We had conversation upon various topics, and particularly on the recent disorders at Harvard University, and the recent change of the system of discipline at the West Point Academy— I called twice at the Bank, and saw Mr Biddle— I met there at one time Mr M’Carty a member of the House of Representatives of the United States from Indiana, and Eleazar Early of Georgia, a man who I once well knew, but whom I had totally forgotten— He now reminded me that he had formerly been a great supporter of Mr Crawford— I said I supposed he was still a great supporter of Mr Crawford— He said yes, but Mr Crawford had lost both his body and mind— I dined with Mr John Connell—Mr. N. Biddle, and Mr Jaudon, W. S. Coxe, Manuel Eyre, Mr Jackson of Newbury-Port who married Louisa Carroll, and Mr Black who has resided many years in China, were the company; with Mrs Connell— In the Evening I walked home with Mr Biddle, and had a further long Conversation with him— Left him just as Mrs Biddle had returned from a ride into the Country— I came home, and sat about an hour with Mr Webster— I found with him Mr W. B. Reed and a young Mr Sergeant— Mr Webster told me that the correspondence of the Senatorial investigating Committee with the President of the U.S. Bank was satisfactory. I received a second Letter from my Son John, written yesterday.
9. IV. Wednesday.

Mr Webster went for New-York, by the 6 O’Clock boat this morning— At Breakfast time I met Mr Burch, of the Clerk’s Office, H.R.U.S. who told me that he saw Mr Forsyth’s Son in Law, Sheaf, fall instantly dead, in one of the Office-rooms of the Treasury Department on Monday— Mr Leaming paid me a long morning visit, and we had much Conversation on political prospects.— He appears not to be sanguine of the success of the whig cause in this State— The name of whigs has very recently been assumed by the motley combination united in nothing but opposition to Jackson’s Administration— There is no common cement among them, and they will jointly, severally and signally fail— The heat continues so intense, that I kept my chamber till the approach of two O’Clock P.M. when I walked down to the wharf to see the Boat from Newcastle of the Baltimore line come in— It arrived, precisely at two— Mr Wilson with my Horses and Carriage, were on board, but not my wife— Wilson said one of his horses was sick— Towards evening I received a Letter from my Son John, saying that his mother had by advice of Dr Huntt concluded not to leave Washington yesterday. I dined lightly at the common Hall and spent the afternoon in Solitude in my chamber, reading about Pestalozzi and Hazlitt’s tour in France— After Sunset Mr Biddle came, and I walked with him to his House, where I saw Mrs Biddle, and sat conversing with him till the watchmen announced past eleven O’Clock— I then walked home— I observed a thermometer at the door of a shop on the South side of Chesnut-street, marking in the shade 96— Mr Biddle told me, that R. Rush very shortly before his tangent flight from Antimasonry, had been exceedingly earnest to make it the great instrument for putting down Jacksonism. He said also that Rush had applied for employment by the Bank— Particularly for the Office of President of the U.S. Branch Bank at Washington or for a Mission from the Bank to England or Holland— I told Mr Biddle, that my kindness for Mr Rush had anxiously sought for some apology or palliation, and that I had been able to discover none other than insanity.—
10. IV:30. Thursday.

Light Showers this morning and a change of temperature gradually cooling, through the day— I sent off Wilson with the Horses and Carriage, for New York— Mr Reed called upon me, and spent an hour in conversation with me. He enquired if I had been acquainted with his Grandfather Joseph Reed at one time President of Pennsylvania, under her first Revolutionary Constitution— I had not. He shewed me a Letter from my father to him written in February 1784—at the Hague—Mr Reed being then in London, after the Peace of 1783— He soon after returned to this Country, and died in 1785— The weather though much moderated was yet too warm for me to pay or return visits— I wrote to my Son John, and just before two O’Clock went again to the wharf hoping that my wife would be coming in the Boat from Newcastle— I was again disappointed. Precisely at two the Robert Morris came in— Mr Wilde of Georgia was on board; having left Washington yesterday at 2 O’Clock, and Baltimore this morning, but he had neither seen nor heard, any thing of Mrs Adams— Returning from the Boat I stopp’d at Dobson’s, Book seller’s shop, and purchased Herschel’s Treatise on Astronomy— Mr Biddle had sent me over the morning newspapers, in one of which I found the Postmaster General Barry’s Address to the People of the United States in defence of himself against the report of the Senatorial Post-Office Committee, which I read— At dinner I met Mr Bright the English traveller whom I had some weeks since, seen at Washington, and who had brought me a Letter from Jos. Blunt. Towards Evening Mr Wilde called upon me, and said he thought of going to-morrow to New-York. After Sunset as it continued to grow cool, I walked to Mr Biddle’s and he not being at home, called to see Mrs Roberdeau whom I found near in Spruce Street, near 13th. to which she has removed from N. 80 12th Street— Her daughter Selina, was married on the 1st. of this Month to Lieutt. Buchanan of the Navy, and is gone to New-York— Susan the only remaining daughter since the death of Mary, was with her mother— After I returned home Mr Biddle called upon me, and told me he proposed going on Saturday Morning, with his family to spend some weeks at Newport Rhode-Island—
11. V. Friday— 67. From Philadelphia to New-York—

My Birthday— I wrote a Letter to my wife and left it, at the Bar of the United States Hotels to be delivered to her upon her arrival— I called over at the Bank, and saw Mr Biddle who promised to see Mrs Adams immediately after her arrival, if she should come this day; and gave me several of the Morning Newspapers with two of Bell’s weekly Messengers of 12 and 19. May— Met Mr. John Connell in the Street, who walked with me to the Steam-boat Trenton— At 1/2 past ten she left the wharf and at 1/4 past two landed her passengers at Bordentown; after stopping as usual at Burlington at Bristol, and at the landing seven miles above Trenton. We entered immediately the Rail-road Cars, and in two hours and a quarter came 35 miles to Perth-Amboy— The average travelling was 3 1/2 minutes to a Mile— The shortest time within which they traversed a mile was by my Chronometer 3 minutes and 10 Seconds— About four miles on the way from Bordentown, we met the train coming from Perth Amboy and it being a part of the road where the double rail is not yet laid our train was obliged to run back about 2 miles to let the other pass which added 4 miles to our distance and a quarter of an hour to our time— The train stopp’d at Haightstown and atdistances of ten miles each; about 5 minutes each time— I marked and remembered the spot, as near as possible the half-way line where the dreadful Catastrophe happened and from which I so narrowly escaped on the 8th. of last November— I met now the same man, who had been one of the Agents of the Proprietors then— He told me they had never had the slightest accident on the road from that day to this— At Perth-Amboy we took the Steam boat again and at seven in the Evening we landed at New-York— I came to the City-Hotel, where Willard gave me a bed-chamber three Stories high— On my way from the Boat I met Mr Fulton, the member of Congress from Virginia, and at the Hotel, Mr Boott of Boston who told me he had seen me at Paris in 1815— On the passage I was claimed as an old acquaintance by three or four persons whose names I did not recollect or ascertain, and had much conversation with an old Gentleman from Charleston, S.C who spoke of Railways and Insurance Companies and City Ordinances and Orations, and told me he was in his grand climacteric, but I did not discover his name—
12. V:30. Saturday. From New-York— Steamer Boston— Sound

I called this morning at the House of Dr J M. Mathews the President of the New-York University, whom I had promised by Letter so to do— But he was not at home, and his Son a young boy told me he would not be at home to be spoken to till half past four in the afternoon, when I was obliged to repair to the Steam-boat. I walked down Wall Street where I saw workmen demolishing the House of my old friend Daniel M’Cormick, who died not many weeks since aged upwards of eighty— I continued my walk to and far up Pearl Street, and reflected that this was the fiftieth year since I first landed at New-York, and what a world of life I had since then gone through— New-York had then 20000 inhabitants— It has now ten times that number—but not one tenth now of those it had then—perhaps not one hundredth— Not a single one that I know. M’Cormick was the last— I called at the House of Sidney Brooks 86 White Street—but he and his wife have been gone a fortnight to the Springs— At Mr Charles A. Davis’s 365. Broadway— I saw Mrs Davis who is panting to go to Europe— She shewed me two Pictures, lately received from Rome copies one, of a Portrait of Raphael, by himself. The other a Magdalen by Carlo Dolcé, both very beautiful— At two O’Clock I went down to meet the Steam-boat from Perth-Amboy of the Rail-way line; but after a walk of near half an hour on the Battery to and fro I found the boat had got in, before I was at the wharf— Mr Biddle and his family were on board, but not my wife— I returned to the City Hotel to dine and just as I was sitting down to write to my Son John, a Letter from him was brought to me, written on Thursday enclosing one from my wife. She had concluded to wait a few days longer at Washington; chiefly on account of the precarious condition of her brother’s health and life— At four I sent Wilson with the Horses and Carriage and my baggage to the Boat and at five myself embarked in the Steamer Boston Captain Comstock— Mr Biddle with his wife, and three daughters and another young girl were there— Mr Charles A. Davis and Mr Woolsey, with them to take leave— Mr Walker, a fellow passenger with me yesterday in the Railway Car, and sundry others who claim acquaintance with me— Among the rest Mr French of the Clerk’s Office H.R.U.S— Fresh Eastern Breeze— We passed Hell-gate, entered the sound and saw Huntington and Norwalk lights— Fair Evening.
13. IV:30. Sunday— From opposite New-London to Quincy.

The fresh Eastern Breeze, raised a heavy dashing swell, which checked the progress of the Boat, and made her roll, to the loss of colour and of appetite to perhaps one third of the passengers, men, women and children— I rose with the Sun, and found we were only opposite to New London, just entering the passage between Fisher’s Island, and the main land of Connecticut— We passed between the Sisters and when beyond the Eastern end of Fisher’s Island, had a heavy swell and so much motion of the boat that several of the Passengers, men, women and children were thoroughly Sea-sick— A thick fog then came up for about two hours, and our Captain and Helmsman were barely able to discern the passage of Point Judith, by the surge upon the beach— The Light-house was not distinguishable— It was about nine in the morning when the Boat reached the wharf at Newport, and several of the passengers landed, among whom were Mr Biddle and his family— The passage up the river was rapid, and at half past 11. I passed at Providence from the Steam-boat immediately into the Pilot Stage; a new line formed for the express purpose of taking the lead of the Mail— Mr Walker was the only one of my companions from Philadelphia, who continued with me— The others were strangers—one a Woman, Mrs Simmons with a child about 3 years old— They all knew me but I remembered none of them— The Stage was new and an excellent Carriage— The Horses very fine and changed every seven Miles— We travelled without other stoppage than to change which never took five minutes, and in four hours, that is at 1/2 past 3. we were at Alden’s tavern in Dedham— Here I took leave of my Companions and left the Stage— Engaged a young man named M’Intyre, with a Horse and Chaise, which in one hour and a quarter, brought me to my own house at Quincy—which I entered at a quarter before five with a grateful ejaculation of heart for preserving mercy. I found Mr and Mrs Kirke, with their daughter Elizabeth at the House—well—as were the tenant of the farm Carr and his wife— I dined; read a Sermon of Saurin the 7th. of the 5th. volume, upon obscure faith, and four Chapters of Proverbs in Thomson’s Bible; and commenced a Letter to my wife— I left Wilson with the Carriage and Horses on board the Steam-boat at Providence with directions to come on to Walpole this Evening; and the rest of the way to-morrow— I took with me only my small trunk— Rain.
14. V:30. Monday

There was a magnificent Rainbow last Evening, just before Sunset, and it began immediately afterwards, and continued the whole night, pouring part of the time in torrents— The brooks were this day much swollen— This morning after Breakfast I visited my garden, which I found in a state as good as I could expect—most of the places where I had planted my trees, seeds, stones, nuts and acorns overrun with weeds, or ploughed up, scattering all my plantations to the winds— The greatest growth is my buttonwood stake— Then the willows. Honey Locust— Red and English Oaks— I found a wild cherry of the fourth year, bearing fruit—my most troublesome difficulty is to make stems for the seedling trees— There is very little fruit—almost no peaches. Cherries gone and there were very few— The only new seedling trees that I find are black mulberries, of which there are several— No Strawberries from the seed— No walnuts—no Oaks from the Acorn— My nephew and namesake came this morning to see me—followed by three Quakers, one of whom, Calvin Shepherd, introduced first himself and then the two others— Arnett is a travelling preacher, a native of North-Carolina, settled in the State of Ohio, about 50 miles from Cincinnati, and is now visiting various parts of the Country, dispensing the word, as the Spirit moves— They called upon me only from motives of curiosity, and after a short conversation departed— They told me they were of the party in opposition to the doctrines of Elias Hicks— I received three Letters, and finished and despatched the one I had begun last Evening to my wife— At 5 in the afternoon Isaac Hull Adams who is here upon furlough, being a Cadet at West Point, came with his brother John Q. and we all bathed at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf and Creek— The water was fresh, and rather cold from the rains of last Night. I swam less than ten minutes, annoyed by the gadflies. Mr E. Price Greenleaf called upon me, and returned the three Volumes of Michaux’s Silva which I lent him last November— I walked to Mrs Adams’s, my brother’s widow and there spent the Evening— Mr and Mrs Edward Miller came in for half an hour— Louisa C. Smith is there, and Mr Price Greenleaf, came and walked home with me— Mrs Angier is likewise there from Medford, but goes home to-morrow.
15. V:30. Tuesday
Whitney Revd. Peter.
